articles.headline: Obama to Go to Copenhagen With Emissions Target
articles.snippet: President Obama will offer to reduce greenhouse gas emissions “in the range of” 17 percent below 2005 levels by 2020, White House officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama will offer to reduce greenhouse gas emissions “in the range of” 17 percent below 2005 levels by 2020, White House officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is pledging a provisional target for reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in the United States, the first time in more than a decade that an American administration has offered even a tentative promise to reduce production of climate-altering gases, the White House announced Wednesday.

articles.headline: Greenberg and A.I.G. Settle Legal Disputes
articles.snippet: The former chief executive will receive materials to help write a memoir, as well as photographs and a Persian rug.
articles.abstract: The former chief executive will receive materials to help write a memoir, as well as photographs and a Persian rug.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group said on Wednesday that it had settled long-running legal battles with Maurice R. Greenberg, the company’s former chief executive, in an attempt to move past years of costly fighting.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Alaska’s Rural Schools Fight Off Extinction
articles.snippet: As Alaska’s rural population dwindles, dozens of its schools are at risk of being closed because of declining enrollment.
articles.abstract: As Alaska’s rural population dwindles, dozens of its schools are at risk of being closed because of declining enrollment.
articles.lead_paragraph: NIKOLSKI, Alaska  This distant dot in the Aleutian Islands needed just 10 students for its school to dodge a fatal cut from the state budget. It reached across Alaska and beyond but could find only nine.

articles.headline: Novel Now, but Not for Long
articles.snippet: This year has produced many gadgets — high-tech and low — that point toward the future.
articles.abstract: This year has produced many gadgets — high-tech and low — that point toward the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: We like to think we’re so advanced, you know? We’re so modern. We’re not like our ancestors, whom we picture exclusively in black-and-white, running around in jerky fast motion. How quaint they were with their Model T’s and gas lamps!

articles.headline: Retailers Extend Deals Beyond Black Friday
articles.snippet: A new pricing strategy by stores gives shoppers a break from the bruising crowds on Friday.
articles.abstract: A new pricing strategy by stores gives shoppers a break from the bruising crowds on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attention shoppers: It might pay to just sleep in this Black Friday.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Businesses in U.S. Brace for New Rules on Emissions
articles.snippet: Much of corporate America has already been thinking about how to comply with sharp cuts when they come, and that day seems to have moved closer.
articles.abstract: Much of corporate America has already been thinking about how to comply with sharp cuts when they come, and that day seems to have moved closer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s corporations have long been bracing for the day when they would be required to carry out sharp cuts in the emissions that cause global warming. That day seemed to move a bit closer on Wednesday, when President Obama outlined a national target for such reductions.

articles.headline: Heritage Turkeys Selling Briskly, Even at $10 a Pound
articles.snippet: A trend for birds that are said to be more flavorful, but cost more and take longer to raise.
articles.abstract: A trend for birds that are said to be more flavorful, but cost more and take longer to raise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Handmade chocolates, artisanal cheeses, vintage Champagne  consumers are thinking twice about splurging on such luxurious goods during the tough economic times. But sales of at least one fancy food item have held up: gourmet turkeys that easily cost $100 or more.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks More Allied Troops for Afghanistan
articles.snippet: NATO allies appear willing to send fewer than half that number of additional troops to Afghanistan as part of President Obama’s strategy for the region, officials said.
articles.abstract: NATO allies appear willing to send fewer than half that number of additional troops to Afghanistan as part of President Obama’s strategy for the region, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States is scrambling to coax NATO allies to send 10,000 additional troops to Afghanistan as part of President Obama’s strategy for the region. Those countries appear willing to provide fewer than half that number, American and allied officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Steven Erlanger
